awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2018 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Sarah Cannon  is " Mathematical Foundations of Markov Chains". The host institution for the fellowship is the University of California, Berkeley and the sponsoring scientist is Alistair Sinclair.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The PI explored the mathematics behind Markov chains and other random sampling algorithms. A main focus was on learning a new technique for random sampling known as the cluster expansion. The PI spent several months learning the mathematics behind this approach, and then was able to apply it in two completely different setting: (1) developing a polynomial time algorithm for random sampling of independent sets in unbalanced bipartite graphs, and (2) proving a Markov-chain based distributed algorithm for particle systems has multiple phases of behavior. The PI also began studying the Markov chains used to sample random political districting plans.  

Intellectual Merit: Work by the PI and collaborators showed a much larger class of bipartite graphs that was previously known has a polynomial time random sampling algorithm. The complexity of the problem of randomly sampling independent sets in bipartite graphs is a big open question, and this work made a step towards resolving it by showing more graphs than were previously known do in fact have a polynomial time algorithm.  Additionally, one lesser-known aspect of the cluster expansion is the fact that if can be used to get a boundary-volume decomposition - this is well known in the statistical physical literature, but hadn't appeared in any recent computer science papers using the cluster expansion. The PI brought this boundary-volume decomposition that comes with the cluster expansion into the computer science literature (including by presenting simplified proofs of it) and connected the cluster expansion with an area it previously had not been used in: distributed algorithms for particle systems. 

Broader Impacts: The PI spent Summer 2019 as a faculty member at a student summer research program, the Voting Rights Data Institute, at Tufts University and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. This summer research program focused on supporting student from underrepresented backgrounds or who did not have as many research opportunities at their home institutions. Weekly student projects focused on using math, data, and more to understand voting, political districting, and how to prevent/detect gerrymandering. For example, in one project, the PI and a group of six students explored how to find political districting plans that have many districts giving a minority population a chance to elect a representative of choice, which is an important first step for litigation of the Voting Rights Act; this later turned into an academic paper written by the PI and four of the students.

Modified by: Sarah Cannon
